description: From Middle English thrasshen, a dialectal variant of thresshen, threshen (whence the modern English thresh), from Old English þrescan, from Proto-Germanic *þreskaną, whence also Old High German dreskan, Old Norse þreskja.

entries.meaning: (countable) A beat or blow; the sound of beating.
examples: As he reeled on wide-braced legs, sobbing for breath, the jungle and the moon swimming bloodily to his sight, the thrash of bat-wings was loud in his ears.

verbs.description: thrash (third-person singular simple present thrashes, present participle thrashing, simple past and past participle thrashed)

entries.meaning: To move about wildly or violently; to flail; to labour.
examples: I rather would be Maevius, thrash for rhymes, / Like his, the scorn and scandal of the times.

entries.meaning: (software) To extensively test a software system, giving a program various inputs and observing the behavior and outputs that result.
(computing) In computer architecture, to cause or undergo poor performance of a virtual memory (or paging) system.
